speaker: James
text: The US-Taiwan trade deal, February 2026. $250 billion in investment for American chip production. Tariffs at 15%. Unthinkable a decade ago, wouldn't you say?

speaker: Elena
text: Unthinkable? Perhaps. Necessary? I'm not so sure. It sounds suspiciously like protectionism.

speaker: James
text: [dry] And what's wrong with that, Elena? For five centuries, every powerful nation built its strength on protected manufacturing. Free trade was the aberration.

speaker: Elena
text: Come on. Globalisation brought cheaper goods, consumer choice. You can't just ditch that for… state factories.

speaker: James
text: Cheaper goods, yes. But at what cost? We offshored everything, then discovered we couldn't make a surgical mask during a pandemic.

speaker: Elena
text: That was an emergency. Not a reason to rewrite forty years of economic policy.

speaker: James
text: [emphatic] The article calls it a 'strategic subsidy' — our 'free trade' was a Cold War tactic. We traded manufacturing jobs for military alliances.

speaker: Elena
text: So, it wasn't about economic efficiency at all? Just geopolitics?

speaker: James
text: Precisely. And China weaponised that system. They systematically moved up the value chain, backed by state subsidies and IP theft.

speaker: Elena
text: That's a convenient reading of the data, James. Many Western companies willingly went to China for cheap labour.

speaker: James
text: And now we see the consequences. Remember "Europe Rearms"? The EU couldn't deliver a million artillery shells to Ukraine.

speaker: Elena
text: Right. Capacity issues.

speaker: James
text: Exactly. Europe's GDP is ten times Russia's, but it can't produce a fraction of Russia's military output. That's a direct result of deindustrialisation.

speaker: Elena
text: Okay, that's... actually devastating. But you can't just mandate factories into existence.

speaker: James
text: Hamilton did. In 1791. High tariffs, subsidies, infrastructure, recruiting skilled workers. America was the most protectionist economy for 150 years. Look what happened.

speaker: Elena
text: But that was a different era. You can't compare 18th-century America to today's global economy.

speaker: James
text: [amused] Friedrich List said free trade was "kicking away the ladder" — Britain did it, then told everyone else ladders were inefficient.

speaker: Elena
text: So you're saying it's all just national self-interest, always has been?

speaker: James
text: Mostly. And now, technology is changing the calculus entirely.

speaker: Elena
text: How so?

speaker: James
text: AI and robotics. The labour cost advantage is disappearing. A robot factory in Ohio costs roughly the same as one in Guangdong.

speaker: Elena
text: Wait, really? That completely undercuts the whole 'cheap labour' argument for offshoring.

speaker: James
text: [thoughtful] It does. If labour costs equalise, then proximity to market, supply chain resilience, and geopolitical stability become the deciding factors. We discussed this in our "Robotics and Slavery" piece.

speaker: Elena
text: I hadn't thought of it that way. So, the economic case for offshoring just... evaporates?

speaker: James
text: Largely. Morgan Stanley predicts 2026 is an inflection point for American manufacturing transformation. Companies are investing in automation now, preparing for greenfield factories at home.

speaker: Elena
text: Well... okay, that's harder to argue with than I expected. The pure economics are shifting.

speaker: James
text: It's a return to the historical norm. A virtuous cycle: factories, skilled workers, innovation, new industries.

speaker: Elena
text: But what about consumer prices? Will we just be paying more for everything?

speaker: James
text: Perhaps initially. But the 'cheap' Chinese goods had hidden costs: lost jobs, hollowed-out communities, strategic vulnerability. We're now paying those.

speaker: Elena
text: I suppose so. Like our article on "Crisis: The Decline of the West" highlighted, the long-term costs often outweigh the short-term gains.

speaker: James
text: Precisely. And nations that fail to rebuild? The article ends with a stark warning: late Rome. Wealthy on paper, dependent on others for everything essential.

speaker: Elena
text: Outsourcing its military, its agriculture... becoming strategically vulnerable. It's a chilling parallel.

speaker: James
text: Chilling, but accurate. The factories are coming back. The only question is which nations build them fast enough.

speaker: Elena
text: And whether that leads to a new kind of economic rivalry. A less cooperative, more mercantilist world.

speaker: James
text: Or a more resilient one. Perhaps both. History, as ever, rhymes.
